Frank Thomson Scholarships.

The children of the late Frank
G. Thomson, former president of
the Pennsylvania Railroad Lines,
established, in 1907, the Frank
Thomson Scholarships, as a memorial to their father. A sum of one
hundred and twenty thousand dollars was set aside as an income.
Each scholarship is worth six hundred dollars a year. Two are
awarded each year, so that there
are always eight Frank Thomson
Scholarship men in college.
The successful competitors for
the scholarships this year were
Henry Grove Rutledge, of Perryville, Md., and Joseph Sommers, of
Oneida, Ohio.
The scholarships are awarded on
a strictly competitive basis. Rutledge made a total of fiften points,
the highest number attainable.

Dean Believes in Football.

Dean Edward H. Griffin does not
agree with Colonel Townsley, superintendent of West Point, who has
recommended that football be abolished at the Military Academy.
Dean Griffin said that he did not
want to appear to criticise the head
of another institution, but that .he
thought football ought to be continued as a college sport. He added,
however, that it ought not to interfere with the students' work.

BALTIMORE, MD., OCT. 20, 1913.
Prize Contest.

For the best Hopkins song, five
dollars, and for the best yell, three
dollars, are the prizes jointly offered
by the Student Council and THE
NEws-LETTER, in a competition
thrown open to the students of the
University, to aid the Booster's
Club.
We need a song like Princeton'p
"Nassau," to be sung when the team
is in the last ditch. "Rah For the
Black and Blue" and "Our Alma
Mater in Dixie Land" are unsuited
to this purpose, while "Veritas Vos
Liberabit" is too staid. Though a
song of the "Nassau" type is desirable, an excellent "rag" like
"We've Got Sand in Our MakeUp," or "We Want a Game," would
receive consideration. The judges
will of course take into considerathe facility with which the student
body can learn a "raggy" composition.
And the yells, to stand consideration, must not be an ingenious copy
of other "sirens" or "locomotives"—
they must be original. Hopkins to
date has three yells. We need more.
The method of awarding the
prizes will be as follows: three
judges, appointed by the Student
Council, will pass on the songs and
yells. The six best of both kinds
will be printed in THE NEws-LETtrEn, and the same edition will contain a ballot to be sent to the chairman of the awarding committee.
Any subscriber to THE NEWSLETTER is entitled to one vote. The
names of voters must be written on
the ballot. The song and yell receiving the highest vote will win
the prize. The unsuccessful contributions will be considered the
property of the student body.
Those wishing to enter the contest must hand in their contributions by next Saturday. Hand con-

CLARENCE WATKINS

At the first meeting of the sophomore class the following resolutions
were passed concerning the death
of Clarence Watkins, who was
drowned at Eaglesmere last summer:
WHEREAS, It has pleased God in
His infinite wisdom to take from
our midst our esteemed friend and
honored classmate Clarence Watkins; and
•
WHEREAS, We the Class of 1916

Retrospective.

This issue contains a feature
which the editors have long contemplated—a sort of "Thirty-yearsago-today" column. The material
for this comes from some motheaten volumes of THE NEWS-LETTER
which have fallen into the hands
of the editor.
To the alumni this column should
be of particular interest. As they
read some long-forgotten college
prank, sweet memories of those
"shortest years of life," will come
sweeping over them.
A comparison between what men
were in college to what they are
in after life can't help but be entertaining.
And for the men in college, a
column of this sort has its appeal.
Call it ancestor worship, if you will,
but worship of ancestors such as
ours can be extremely beneficial.
The football and lacrosse teams of
a decade ago, as the Trophy Room
bears witness, pulled down many
a State and national championship.
While the musical clubs of that date
had audiences which would make
our•"houses" look like chapel on a
rainy morning.

At the first meeting of the Athletic Association on Monday, October 13, it was decided to send
"Butts" Sutton and "Father Bill"
Schmeisser as delegates to the annual meeting of the Intercollegiate
Lacrosse League in New York. The
delegates went to New York Saturday morning, as the meeting was
held at two o'clock that afternoon.
One of the most important things
done at this meeting was the official
awarding of the championship banners to both the Northern and
Southern divisions of the League.
Harvard won the championship of
the Northern division, while we
won that of the Southern division.
Tt will also be remembered by the
faithful that we beat Harvard in
the final game for the championship
of the United States.
The University of Pennsylvania
has applied for admission to the
League. This will bring the number of colleges in the Southern
division up to four.

THE NEWS—LETTER, OCTOBER 20, 1913.
THE MUSICAL CLUBS ORGANIZE
New Leaders Are Elected, and Outlook
for the Coming Season Is Good.
Places to Be Visited.

The first meeting of the Musical
Clubs was held last Friday at one
o'clock. Retiring-President Gillet
presided and took charge of the
elections. Mr. Robert J. Scovell
was elected president; Mr. H. Huntley Lloyd was re-elected leader of
the Glee Club, and Mr. Walter Geisse was chosen to lead the Instrumental Club.
It was decided to continue last
year's practice of having graduate
and undergraduate managers. Mr.
Fulton was elected graduate manager, and Mr. Richard Coblentz
undergraduate manager. Several
of the new men were tried out by
the new president, after which the
old men rendered several of last
year's hits, just to show that they
still knew how to sing. The two
leaders of the Clubs wish it distinctly understood that freshmen are
Just as eligible for membership as
others. They are urged to watch
the bulletins for announcements of
the first rehearsals, which will come
in the near future. Leader Geissel
will especially welcome violinists to
the Club.
The managers are already planning an attractive schedule for the
musicians. Wilmington, Frederick,
Dover, Hagerstown and Westminster are being spoken of as probable places where the Clubs will
entertain. Come out early so that
You can enjoy all the fun.
Engineering Society.

The first meeting of the Johns
Hopkins Engineering Society will
be held on Friday, October 24, at
one o'clock, in the Physical Laboratory, Room No. 18. All technical students are invited to attend
this meeting and to become members of the Society. Prof. J. B.
Whitehead, head of the Department
of Electrical Engineering, will address the meeting.
The Engineering Society was
formally organized on November II,
1Q12, for the investigation and discussion of technological topics. Its
general scope is similar to that of
the technical societies at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology,
and at Cornell.
During the past year bi-monthly
meetings were regularly held. These
meetine-s were addressed by professors of the University and by engineers of national reputation. The
officers of the Society are:
A. Tobias, president; S. L. Leithiser, vice-president, and H. W.
Woodward, secretary.

Rhodes Scholarships Exams.

Another chapter was begun in the
old, old story of Hopkins versus
St. John's in the assembly room of
McCoy Hall last Tuesday and Wednesday when qualifying examination for the Rhodes Scholarships
were held. Considering the payment of $15o per year and three
years' residence in Europe, the
number of men that took the "exams" was remai-kably small.
A. K. Barton,'14; J. H. Marshall,
'13, and Carl Weber, '14, defended
the Black and Blue against Fell, the
single entrant from St. John's. The
contest was not so one-sided as it
might seem, however, for Fell is
an athlete, and at St. John's made
492 points out of a possible 500 in
his studies. What became of the
other eight is not known.
The Hopkins men were rather
reticent in stating what percentage
they had made, but it is to be hoped
that one of the three at least answered correctly the questions put
by the Oxford "profs."

October 15, 1913.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
I read with much disgust the
article by "Charlemagne" in your
issue of last week. Such an attempt at wit is unworthy of the
rest of your articles. Please do not
print any more of "Charlemagne's"
effusions.
Some men around the University seem to think that hazing is an
awful lot of fun. No doubt some
of them thought they had the time
of their young lives the night of
the Young Men's Christian Association reception. But if I may use
a little of your space, I may lie able
to convince you of the error of this
point of view.
Now, I, myself, am very fond of
swimming. In the summer time, I
enjoy nothing more than a plunge
in some rural stream or flowing
estuary. But in the place where
I come from, we do not consider
October as coming in the summer
time, and when the time of the year
is not summer it is customary for
water to have a lower temperature.
Moreover, I always go swimming
in the day time.
In the night, the heat from the
sun's rays is gradually dispersed
and the temperature falls. This
fall in temperature has a common
effect upon water. So that water
in October, and in the night time,
is not just the sort of fluid I have
been accustomed to perform by ablutions in.
No doubt you have heard of the
compulsory bath several of my
classmates and I took after the
Young Men's Christian Association
reception. I am not grumbling,
about it, not complaining,. I merely
want to urge you not to believe anyone who will tell you that hazing
is a lot of fun. Believe me, it isn't;
and I know.
Refrigeratorially,.

'takes place on Thanksgiving Day,
and is the last game of the season.
The Soldier boys made a slightly
better showing against Washington
and Lee than the 'Varsity did, but
on Saturday last played a poor
game against Franklin and Marshall, being defeated 46 to o. They
were. decidedly crippled, however,
three regulars being out of the
game. At the present time it looks
like anybody's game if both teams
are kept intact.

Frank Thomson Scholarships.

The children of the late Frank
G. Thomson, former president of
the Pennsylvania Railroad Lines,
established, in 1907, the Frank
Thomson Scholarships, as a memorial to their father. A sum of one
hundred and twenty thousand dollars was set aside as an income.
Each scholarship is worth six hundred dollars a year. Two are
awarded each year, so that there
are always eight Frank Thomson
Scholarship men in college.
The successful competitors for
the scholarships this year were
Henry Grove Rutledge, of Perryville, Md., and Joseph Sommers, of
Oneida, Ohio.
The scholarships are awarded on
a strictly competitive basis. Rutledge made a total of fiften points,
the highest number attainable.

Dean Believes in Football.

Dean Edward H. Griffin does not
agree with Colonel Townsley, superintendent of West Point, who has
recommended that football be abolished at the Military Academy.
Dean Griffin said that he did not
want to appear to criticise the head
of another institution, but that .he
thought football ought to be continued as a college sport. He added,
however, that it ought not to interfere with the students' work.

Prize Contest.

For the best Hopkins song, five
dollars, and for the best yell, three
dollars, are the prizes jointly offered
by the Student Council and THE
NEws-LETTER, in a competition
thrown open to the students of the
University, to aid the Booster's
Club.
We need a song like Princeton'p
"Nassau," to be sung when the team
is in the last ditch. "Rah For the
Black and Blue" and "Our Alma
Mater in Dixie Land" are unsuited
to this purpose, while "Veritas Vos
Liberabit" is too staid. Though a
song of the "Nassau" type is desirable, an excellent "rag" like
"We've Got Sand in Our MakeUp," or "We Want a Game," would
receive consideration. The judges
will of course take into considerathe facility with which the student
body can learn a "raggy" composition.
And the yells, to stand consideration, must not be an ingenious copy
of other "sirens" or "locomotives"—
they must be original. Hopkins to
date has three yells. We need more.
The method of awarding the
prizes will be as follows: three
judges, appointed by the Student
Council, will pass on the songs and
yells. The six best of both kinds
will be printed in THE NEws-LETtrEn, and the same edition will contain a ballot to be sent to the chairman of the awarding committee.
Any subscriber to THE NEWSLETTER is entitled to one vote. The
names of voters must be written on
the ballot. The song and yell receiving the highest vote will win
the prize. The unsuccessful contributions will be considered the
property of the student body.
Those wishing to enter the contest must hand in their contributions by next Saturday. Hand con-

Retrospective.

This issue contains a feature
which the editors have long contemplated—a sort of "Thirty-yearsago-today" column. The material
for this comes from some motheaten volumes of THE NEWS-LETTER
which have fallen into the hands
of the editor.
To the alumni this column should
be of particular interest. As they
read some long-forgotten college
prank, sweet memories of those
"shortest years of life," will come
sweeping over them.
A comparison between what men
were in college to what they are
in after life can't help but be entertaining.
And for the men in college, a
column of this sort has its appeal.
Call it ancestor worship, if you will,
but worship of ancestors such as
ours can be extremely beneficial.
The football and lacrosse teams of
a decade ago, as the Trophy Room
bears witness, pulled down many
a State and national championship.
While the musical clubs of that date
had audiences which would make
our•"houses" look like chapel on a
rainy morning.

At the first meeting of the Athletic Association on Monday, October 13, it was decided to send
"Butts" Sutton and "Father Bill"
Schmeisser as delegates to the annual meeting of the Intercollegiate
Lacrosse League in New York. The
delegates went to New York Saturday morning, as the meeting was
held at two o'clock that afternoon.
One of the most important things
done at this meeting was the official
awarding of the championship banners to both the Northern and
Southern divisions of the League.
Harvard won the championship of
the Northern division, while we
won that of the Southern division.
Tt will also be remembered by the
faithful that we beat Harvard in
the final game for the championship
of the United States.
The University of Pennsylvania
has applied for admission to the
League. This will bring the number of colleges in the Southern
division up to four.

THE NEWS—LETTER, OCTOBER 20, 1913.
THE MUSICAL CLUBS ORGANIZE
New Leaders Are Elected, and Outlook
for the Coming Season Is Good.
Places to Be Visited.

The first meeting of the Musical
Clubs was held last Friday at one
o'clock. Retiring-President Gillet
presided and took charge of the
elections. Mr. Robert J. Scovell
was elected president; Mr. H. Huntley Lloyd was re-elected leader of
the Glee Club, and Mr. Walter Geisse was chosen to lead the Instrumental Club.
It was decided to continue last
year's practice of having graduate
and undergraduate managers. Mr.
Fulton was elected graduate manager, and Mr. Richard Coblentz
undergraduate manager. Several
of the new men were tried out by
the new president, after which the
old men rendered several of last
year's hits, just to show that they
still knew how to sing. The two
leaders of the Clubs wish it distinctly understood that freshmen are
Just as eligible for membership as
others. They are urged to watch
the bulletins for announcements of
the first rehearsals, which will come
in the near future. Leader Geissel
will especially welcome violinists to
the Club.
The managers are already planning an attractive schedule for the
musicians. Wilmington, Frederick,
Dover, Hagerstown and Westminster are being spoken of as probable places where the Clubs will
entertain. Come out early so that
You can enjoy all the fun.
Engineering Society.

The first meeting of the Johns
Hopkins Engineering Society will
be held on Friday, October 24, at
one o'clock, in the Physical Laboratory, Room No. 18. All technical students are invited to attend
this meeting and to become members of the Society. Prof. J. B.
Whitehead, head of the Department
of Electrical Engineering, will address the meeting.
The Engineering Society was
formally organized on November II,
1Q12, for the investigation and discussion of technological topics. Its
general scope is similar to that of
the technical societies at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology,
and at Cornell.
During the past year bi-monthly
meetings were regularly held. These
meetine-s were addressed by professors of the University and by engineers of national reputation. The
officers of the Society are:
A. Tobias, president; S. L. Leithiser, vice-president, and H. W.
Woodward, secretary.

Rhodes Scholarships Exams.

Another chapter was begun in the
old, old story of Hopkins versus
St. John's in the assembly room of
McCoy Hall last Tuesday and Wednesday when qualifying examination for the Rhodes Scholarships
were held. Considering the payment of $15o per year and three
years' residence in Europe, the
number of men that took the "exams" was remai-kably small.
A. K. Barton,'14; J. H. Marshall,
'13, and Carl Weber, '14, defended
the Black and Blue against Fell, the
single entrant from St. John's. The
contest was not so one-sided as it
might seem, however, for Fell is
an athlete, and at St. John's made
492 points out of a possible 500 in
his studies. What became of the
other eight is not known.
The Hopkins men were rather
reticent in stating what percentage
they had made, but it is to be hoped
that one of the three at least answered correctly the questions put
by the Oxford "profs."

October 15, 1913.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
I read with much disgust the
article by "Charlemagne" in your
issue of last week. Such an attempt at wit is unworthy of the
rest of your articles. Please do not
print any more of "Charlemagne's"
effusions.
Some men around the University seem to think that hazing is an
awful lot of fun. No doubt some
of them thought they had the time
of their young lives the night of
the Young Men's Christian Association reception. But if I may use
a little of your space, I may lie able
to convince you of the error of this
point of view.
Now, I, myself, am very fond of
swimming. In the summer time, I
enjoy nothing more than a plunge
in some rural stream or flowing
estuary. But in the place where
I come from, we do not consider
October as coming in the summer
time, and when the time of the year
is not summer it is customary for
water to have a lower temperature.
Moreover, I always go swimming
in the day time.
In the night, the heat from the
sun's rays is gradually dispersed
and the temperature falls. This
fall in temperature has a common
effect upon water. So that water
in October, and in the night time,
is not just the sort of fluid I have
been accustomed to perform by ablutions in.
No doubt you have heard of the
compulsory bath several of my
classmates and I took after the
Young Men's Christian Association
reception. I am not grumbling,
about it, not complaining,. I merely
want to urge you not to believe anyone who will tell you that hazing
is a lot of fun. Believe me, it isn't;
and I know.
Refrigeratorially,.

FRESHMAN.
The man who goes around singing his own praises is generally a
solo singer with a poor song.
